page.title: 01Strome and environs
page.content: To the north and south of Loch Carron, this is a sparsely populated area of great natural beauty. The land rises from the sea loch to hills, crags and mountains. The mostly rocky coastline is indented by small bays, coves and beaches(some sandy) and includes two estuaries. Primary land cover is coniferous forestry commission plantation: native oak and birch also occur. Additionally, land is used for grazing and pasture, and there is open heath. Historically interesting is the ruin of Strome castle, dramatically situated on a rocky promontory looking west over the sea to Skye. The mostly native population resides mainly in small enclaves at Strome Ferry, Port Chullin and North Strome. Occupations include crofting, forestry, fishing and oil-rig construction at nearby Kishorn.
